111.content: As the Hyenas are pretty much a non entity of the pride lands, Simbas time has pretty much been taken up with sleeping and eating. Nothign much else to do other then average kingly duties. The king though has been utting on a little weight, a much mroe noticable belly but thats pretty usual. For now.
111.title: Simba

choices: ...The snake struck too quickly for him to dodge
...The dart seemed to come out of nowhere
1111.content:
As Simba lay back after lunch, he could feel the heavy weight of his large meal, pushing his gut out and making him look fat. Others - if they'd known his thoughts on the matter, and been brave enough to speak out - would have disagreed, for although the large meal did indeed make the king's belly look much more rotund than normal, in fact his belly was visual proof that his weight had been rising slowly for some time.

In the early days, much of the gain had been in muscle mass - the amount of time he was spending on his paws had risen dramatically since he's returned - which had seen his form expand, from the slender gangliness of a rogue, to the powerful stockiness of a king. As the Pridelands were becoming bountiful once again though, the amount of exercise he was getting was starting to plateau, and thus, so was the development of his musculature.

Simba wasn't aware of this though, as indeed he'd hardly been aware of any growth in the first place, and so made no move to curtail the amount he ate. None of the lionesses had shown any concern over how much the king ate either, and certainly none of them him a greedy or gluttonous lion by any means, but given the number of successful hunts and the amount the lionesses were bringing back each time, the volume of meat he was consuming these days was slightly more than was his busy yet measured lifestyle was allowing him to shed. Some of the excess was just starting to become a thin blanket beneath his pelt, softening his muscular appearance very slightly, but a good portion of was finding its way to his abdomen, resulting in his now starting to carry a small, yet portentous belly.

None of the lionesses had yet to notice Simba's new belly against the background of his general muscular expansion, nor had his friends Timon and Pumbaa, and if his aides Zazu and Rafiki had noticed it, they'd kept it to themselves.
-------
Slightly less than an hour after he'd finished eating, Simba was awoken from his engorged slumber by a noise nearby. Partially awoken anyway, it took a little time, and some persistence on the part of Zazu before he was fully awake enough to sigh at the situation, "you couldn't have left it a bit longer could you Zazu?"

"Would that I could sire," Zazu replied, though he didn't seem regretful in the least as far as Simba could tell, "but you should know by now that the life of a king is not meant to be easy."

Simba glared at Zazu for a moment, but the hornbill only stared right back, not seeming the least bit afraid, though he did flinch a little when one of the lionesses asked tiredly, "how much trouble would it be to replace him?"

"More than I'd like," Simba replied, then yawned widely, before arising with a groan.

"Do you really need to go," Nala asked, shooting Zazu a black look, "can't it wait?"

"I only wish it could Simba replied, bending down to share a nuzzle, " but Zazu's right, I'm a king, so I have certain duties."

"Well just as long as you remember you have duties back here as well," Nala smiled, "good luck out there."

"Thanks," Simba replied, then stretched, and groaned, "uurgh, that'll teach me not to each big meals when I know I'm not going to get hours to digest it." With a last sigh, he said, "I'll try not to be too long, but I can't make promises," then started to pad down towards the savannah.

Simba's mood didn't improve as he left Pride Rock behind, not only was the afternoon heat stifling, but his engorged stomach vibrated slightly with each step, which was just nauseating enough to feel uncomfortable. Unfortunately his day wasn't about to improve any time soon as...
1111.title: Growing Into His Position

choices: Place a fattening curse on Simba
1113.content:
One day Simba wakes up and sees a black rabbit with red eyes staring at him.

what does it do?
1113.title: A fattening curse...

11131.content:
Simba watches the rabbit for a few seconds. It doesn't move, and just stares intently at him. "Easy kill", Simba thinks, and decides to pounce. However, when he reached the apex of his leap, he was surprised to see the rabbit suddenly dodge out of his immediate grasp. Simba landed peacefully on the ground, but spun and growled at his target, who... seemed to fade away?

Yes, Simba couldn't believe his eyes. The rabbit seems to disintegrate into thin air, with only a few small particles of dust seeming to remain. The wind catches the dust, and throws it into Simba's face. Simba coughs and sneezes a few times, feeling congested at first and then becoming confused and disoriented. Suddenly, a high pitched, evil voice sounds in his ears.

"Hello, King Lion. I am, what you call, the Spirit of the Jungle. Had you left me be, I'd have given you the best luck and life imaginable, in thanks for your kindness. However, despite your very successful current life where you lacked not for food, you still decided to attack an animal with nothing to do with you."

"So, you're hungry, huh? Want to eat some more right now? Well, I'm going to make it so you never want to eat again. Honestly, you may never do so. Kumlai durhena!"

Just like that, the voice disappears. Simba, unsure of what had just happened, decides to take a walk.
11131.title: Place a fattening curse on Simba

choices: Oh, a few more bugs won't hurt
Go find Timon and Pumbaa, they've been fat before
111311.content:
Simba couldn't shake the feeling that something had changed in him after the spirit met him and said that strange, nonsensical curse. Slowly, his mind was thinking increasingly of food, and his stomach suddenly began to growl. "Hoo, boy," he said to himself, "better get something to eat, I'm starving."

The lion quickly ran to the nearest patch of rainforest he could find, desperate for a stream, in whose swampland he could find some bugs. He was too hungry to stand taking down a zebra; Nala usually took care of that stuff anyway, and he didn't trust what'd happen if he screwed up. As he overturned a log, he knew he'd made the right decision. The downed tree was hiding a two-foot deep pit teeming with insects he'd never seen before. They were all different colors, no two colored the same. Simba picked one up to investigate it. It was about half an inch thick, and squishy, too. He popped it in his mouth; it was a fruity sensation he had never tasted before and couldn't get enough of. The lion laid down next to the trough, sticking his face right into the trough to bite into a mouthful. It was the best thing he'd ever tasted. Timon and Pumbaa would be so jealous. As he took another bite, then another, Simba began to feel ecstacy, the taste of the bugs spreading through his body, creating a tingling sensation. This only left the lion to chew away harder and faster, eager to get more of his fix. After another few minutes, the lion sat back, in awe of the bliss. Sighing, he put his paws on his stomach... which was a lot bigger than he remembered.

Simba took a moment to think, then opened his eyes. Yep, that was definitely his tummy, and yep, it was about four inches larger in every direction. He turned off his back, taken aback at the extra difficulty that action asked of him. Padding over to the stream, he checked his reflection. His cheeks had rounded out a bit, while his chin had began to acquire a second one. Checking out his body, he saw he had definitely gained weight, at least a hundred pounds. As the bugs' drug-like effect wore off, the lion felt sudden pangs he couldn't comprehend. If he had just gained a hundred pounds, making him a pretty large lion, he shouldn't want to eat more bugs... but their juicy allure was starting to make his mouth water.
111311.title: He feels odd

choices: Finish the entire trough (gains nearly 1,000 pounds)
Someone finds him and breaks his attention (gains around 400 pounds)
1113111.content:
"I... I'll be fine," Simba said to himself. "This is definitely from the spirit's curse, but a few more minutes won't hurt. These bugs are addicting."

Ignoring all inhibitions, Simba leaped into the trough, surrounding himself with the delicious, rainbow-colored candy-like bugs, quickly shoving pawfuls of the bugs into his mouth. Perfection. The perfect flavor.

The lion slowly drifted into a trance-like state as the bugs' mild venom, meant to slow and relax the body's nervous system, slowly seeped into his skin. "You know, man... this is nice," Simba said to himself between bites. "Just a nice, peaceful little vacation." Though he was loathe to care, Simba's body began again to thicken, his belly's growth outward slowly matched by his legs, down to his paws, then up to his face.
1113111.title: Oh, a few more bugs won't hurt

choices: Simba wakes up to find the trough has refilled itself
11131111.content: As Simba kept filling himself with bug after bug after delicious bug, he had no way of knowing the drastic changes occurring in his body. His belly started rounding outward at a steady pace, while his four limbs and paws followed suit. Essentially, the lion was blowing up like a balloon and almost egging on the growth. By the time he finished the last bug and fell asleep, he was unbelievably big. Rolls of fat covered every part of his body - five chins on his face, ten rolls behind his back and a stretched, taut tummy that drooped down to the ground and then some.
11131111.title: Finish the entire trough (gains nearly 1,000 po...

choices: Timon and Pumbaa snap Simba out of it
Man, those things look good... they join Simba in gluttony
1113112.content:
Before he had a chance to let things get even further out of control, Simba came to his senses and immediately ran to Timon and Pumbaa. In passing, they'd mentioned some ridiculous stories here and there about eating a hundred-foot-long worm, and being hypnotized by snakes, and working to become elephants, and gained huge amounts of magic weight in the process. Though his speed was slowed somewhat by his extra padding, Simba was able to track them down in no time.

"Timon, Pumbaa, I need your help," Simba panted as he sat down next to his friends.

"Oh, hey, Simba! We were just discussing..." Timon welcomed his friend for a minute until he noticed the big change that had just occurred.

"Boy, Simba, you sure do look different. Is it weird that I see myself in you a little bit right now?", Pumbaa blurted out.

Sheepishly, Simba gave a small grin and explained everything to his friends.

"So you have a magic spell on you that makes you get fat, and you found a bunch of magic bugs," Timon said. "That's about right," Simba replied.

"And you haven't brought us to it yet... why?" the meerkat sarcastically asked.

Though he couldn't help but think it was a bad idea, Simba agreed to show his friends the treasure trove he had uncovered. Timon and Pumbaa stared agape at the massive swarm of bugs, grubs and other insects right before their eyes.

At the same time, the call of the curse began to hit Simba harder. His stomach suddenly felt like he hadn't eaten in days, and almost reflexively the lion grabbed a flying bug and shoved it into his mouth. Then another, and another. After a few seconds the lion had his face in the pit again, shoveling the bugs into his mouth using his paws. Timon and Pumbaa could only watch at first as the curse appeared to come true - their friend was slowly but surely expanding outward, his initial hundred pounds marching upward at a muted pace.
1113112.title: Go find Timon and Pumbaa, they've been fat ...

choices: ...He was able to pull himself upright
...He was forced to lie back in defeat
111312.content:
Simba was patrolling the borders near the desert, when he came across an impala, or at least the body of one. This was not an unusual occurrence, even in this sparsely-inhabited corner of the kingdom, there were always a few predators who hung on out here for one reason or another, more as scavengers than predators. None of them had been involved here though, for the carcass was unmarked by either tooth or claw, and indeed there wasn't even the scent of another animal around. This in itself was unusual, even if nothing on the ground spotted a kill, surely a vulture should have spotted this? Stranger still was how the poor beast had died, there were no marks or trauma, yet the carcass was all but surrounded by an air of terror and exhaustion, as though the animal had been running from something and pushed itself too hard, yet what was there out here to run from?

At first, Simba didn't notice his growing hunger, but soon enough he couldn't ignore it, his stomach growling loudly enough to scare off small animals. The king had by now forgotten his earlier encounter with the 'spirit', and so didn't consider that there was anything unusual about the feeling of emptiness except perhaps its intensity, which was soon so overpowering that he couldn't help but dig into the carcass.

Even as Simba devoured the carcass, the hunger didn't seem to abate at all, indeed as his stomach expanded it only seemed to grow. Soon enough, the king's stomach had expanded to its natural limit, beyond which he was in danger of serious injury, but his hunger was by now so intense that even considering slowing down was all but unthinkable, and indeed as he continued to gorge his stomach seemed not to be troubled by its eve-increasing burden, expanding in a way that should not have been possible.

The hunger only finally dropped to a manageable level when Simba was cleaning the last of the flesh from the bones. He wasn't sure precisely how much he'd eaten, but he knew it was much more than he should have, and indeed a fair bit more than he should have been able to. He was by now lying down, his fore-quarters almost upright, but his hind-quarters off to the side to allow his unnaturally engorged belly enough space to not cause too much discomfort, at least physically. The king was very worried, not only had his hunger been quite unnatural he now knew, but the amount he'd consumed had been similarly impossible, or should have been. This in itself presented a problem though, since he had no idea who to tell, the lionesses surely wouldn't be able to do anything, and neither would his friends Timon and Pumbaa, nor Zazu, which left only Rafiki, yes, the old mandrill would be able to help him surely.

With his course decided, Simba was faced with another problem, for the impala had been a well-sized male, and so he'd have to struggle with his stomach, almost twice as big as it should be and twinging painfully simply to get up. Of course, he didn't let that put him off, and so gritted his teeth and started to experiment. After several minutes...
111312.title: Big Meal

1113121.content:
...He was able to pull himself upright, though not without considerable difficulty. Of course, things didn't get much easier once he was upright, his belly was so large that it got him in the way of his hind-legs, forcing him to adopt a something of a waddle simply to avoid poking his knees painfully into his engorged stomach. Still, there was nothing he could about it, Rafiki was the only one who could help him now, and the sooner he set off the sooner he'd arrive.

Simba realised soon enough that he'd be lucky to reach Rafiki's baobab home by nightfall, so slow was his progress, but he was determined to keep on, at least until he caught the scent of water on the breeze, which brought back to him how thirsty he was, and so he debated whether to delay his journey for a time, before his thirst, which had appeared almost as quickly and was almost as strong as his hunger had been all but drove him towards the scent.

The waterhole was small, and seemed to be little-used, but that suited Simba fine, it would be embarrassing to appear to his subject like this in any case. At first he tried to drink standing up, but this proved, with the weight in his gut, and the slope of the bank to be almost impossible, and so he lay down as he had at the carcass, craned his neck forward until he could reach the water and began to drink. He'd not intended to drink much, but as with his meal, an unnatural gluttony overtook him and so he drank until his stomach fairly sloshed, drinking as much as he'd eaten.

When his thirst faded and he was able to take stock of his situation, Simba was dismayed to say the least, the contents of his stomach weighed almost a half of what he did, and he was now so engorged that trying to continue his journey would be impossible, and so he gave up and lay on his side, wondering what was happening, and if there was any way of solving it. As he lay there under the warm sun, with his impossibly bloated stomach starting to work over its incredible meal, he soon began to feel drowsy, and it only increased minute by minute until staying awake was virtually impossible.
------
Simba awoke...
1113121.title: First Experiences

11131211.content:
...Late that night, and after a quick self-examination, was gratified to find that his belly was not only quite a bit smaller, but also rather more malleable, not twinging painfully from being overfull. Realising there wasn't a moment to lose, he struggled upright - a manoeuvre that was a little more difficult than he'd expected it to be despite his still descended belly, and set off.

A few times on his journey Simba tried running, but for some reason never seemed to be able to get up the speed he'd expected to, despite having accounted for his still somewhat distended gut. In this thought at least he was correct, his belly wasn't the sole cause of his loss of speed, indeed no part of his body was solely responsible, because the loss was the result of the cumulative effect each part played. What the king's self-examination hadn't noticed was that although his belly had shrunken, the mass of it - or rather, within it - hadn't simply disappeared, a portion of it had been 'redistributed', to the effect that he now weighed several dozen pounds more than he had before his recent meal, though the difference in any one place was subtle almost to the point of being unnoticeable.

Despite his gain though, Simba made good progress on his journey, until he heard a commotion off to his left. At first he thought nothing of it, until he heard a distinctive giggling that could only have been produced by a hyena. He felt his hackles rise at that, the dirty scavengers were still coming if after dark were they, well he'd have to teach them a lesson so that they wouldn't do it again. Loping off towards the sound, the scene he came across made him angrier than even the simple thought of those mangy beast simply being here, five of the beasts had treed a pregnant leopard and were now feasting on its undoubtedly hard-won kill, this wouldn't do.

The hyenas looked up when Simba roared and retreated quickly when he charged, or at least four did, the fifth wasn't quite fast enough, and was knocked off its feet by a mighty blow, though was able to scramble upright and beat a hasty retreat before the king was able to drag his turgid body around to pin it, following its friends out into the darkness. With the fight over, he stood there, panting slightly for a moment, before remembering the totality of the situation.

To Simba, the now somewhat denuded gazelle looked quite scrumptious, but he held off for a time, because he could feel the leopardess's piercing but fearful gaze on him. For a moment, the king's sense of honour overruled his hunger, the kill rightly belonged to the leopardess, but he was feeling hungry again, and the gazelle looked like it would just about hit the spot. After a few moments deliberation, he...
11131211.title: In The Dark

choices: ...Had never heard of such a spirit
111312112.content:
...Found himself too hungry to leave, and so he moved over to the carcass, his drive to eat growing by the second. He paused a moment as he stood over the carcass, some semblance of self-control still fighting, but the hunger quickly swallowed even that as, a moment later, Simba himself began to swallow.

The gazelle was quite a bit smaller than the impala, and so Simba didn't feel nearly as full when he'd finished it. He did feel guilty though, the carcass should have been the leopardess's, and yet he'd let his hunger get the better of him...

The leopardess glared, half in fear, half in anger, as the lion quickly retreated, That kill had been hers by right, but now it had been taken from her...
-------
With the weight of the meat in his gut, Simba was moving slower now than before, and slower still for his self degradation, what had gotten into him of late, was he now so gluttonous that he simply couldn't refuse any titbit that came his way? And if that was the case, how long would it be before he was incapable of doing his duties?

Fortunately, no other opportunities for gluttony waylaid Simba as he made his way ever-closer to Rafiki's baobab home, though the weight of his most recent meal slowed him down so much that dawn was already breaking by the time he arrived. For a moment, the king thought of waiting until full daylight, but he quickly discounted it, he really needed help now, and so called out, lowly, "Rafiki, Rafiki are you there?"

"I am here," the mandrill replied wearily, "who speaks?"

"It's me, Simba," he replied, "I need your help, and quickly."

"Indeed," mandrill replied, then sighed, "very well sire, what avails you?"
-------
"Hm, a small dark creature with long ears and glowing eyes you say," Rafiki asked. The description troubled him, for he...
111312112.title: Midnight Meal

1113121122.content:
...Knew this one only too well, the Black Leporid.

"Yes," Simba replied, "you know it?"

"I've heard of it before, yes," Rafiki replied, "but I'm afraid I can do little to help, and can guarantee nothing."

"What am I going to do then," Simba asked, "I can't-I can't help but eat any meat I can find, if this keeps up for even just a few more days-"

"Calm yourself sire," Rafiki stopped the lion, "panicking won't help."

"Neither will staying calm though, apparently," Simba replied tensely.

Rafiki sighed, "rest assured sire, I will do what I can."

"And what can I do in the meantime," Simba replied, "I can't possibly go home if my first reaction to any scrap of meat lying around is to devour it, what with the stuff the lionesses bring home I'd be as big as a hippo in no time, and not nearly as mobile."

"Then you shall sleep with me," Rafiki replied, "and it would be best if you were to start now."

"At this time of the day," Simba asked.

"You settle yourself down now and I shall make a potion to help," Rafiki replied firmly.

"But what about my duties," Simba asked.

"They can, I think, hold for a day," Rafiki replied, "now, settle down and sleep."

"I-I'll do my best," Simba replied.

"Very good," Rafiki said, "and I shall be back soon," and with that he turned and climbed back up the tree, firm of purpose. Simba stared after the mandrill for a few moments, but then shook his head, and moving into the shade of the tree, bid his best to settle down, a process, helped by the fact that it was, indeed, not much later when the shaman reappeared with a thick brew that, despite smelling quite foul and tasting not much better, his gluttony forced him to consume down to the last drop. At first, he doubted how much the brew would help, within a few minutes he was fast asleep.

Waiting until Simba was fast asleep, Rafiki once again climbed his tree, this time to commune with the spirits, and hopefully persuade the Black Leporid to agree to some sort of deal. This wouldn't be easy he knew, the spirit was famously vindictive, all too willing to kill each and every predator, despite the fact that this would break the great circle of life wide open.

Fast asleep, and thus for now safe from himself, Simba remained blissfully unaware of all that was going on around him, at least until
1113121122.title: Troubling Spirit

11131211221.content:
...He awoke that evening, feeling refreshed, and peckish. For a few moments he hoped the events of the past day or so might have been a dream, but a quick look back over his expanded frame dashed them. Where once he'd been merely stocky - as any royal lion tended to get after a time - he was now out-and-out rotund, his once defined musculature now less so as a layer of excess flesh softened his appearance, with plenty left over to turn his once tight belly into a round, heavy one. Grimacing at his expansion, Simba nevertheless knew he couldn't wallow in self-pity forever, and so, arose, the action just a little more difficult than he was used to, and made his way over to Rafiki's baobab to see if the mandrill had made any progress.

"Ah, my king, I see you're awake," Rafiki said, before Simba had even made it to the foot of the baobab, "and how are you now?"

"Hungry," Simba replied, "and worried, I've put on a fair amount of weight already, and if this continues..."

"Yes, that would be tricky," Rafiki replied, "however, I have talked to the spirit, and he is willing to offer you a chance to as he calls it 'repent'."

"He will," Simba asked, "and what do I have to do?"

"You must fast, that is, not eat," Rafiki explained, "and you must do it for a period of two days for each animal you have consumed."

Two days, by two animals, Simba calculated quickly, "that's four days."

"Yes, a trying period," Rafiki sighed, "and he also say that if you do eat anything else it will add another two days for each animal."

"That's, that's not going to be easy," Simba replied concernedly, no, that was going to be difficult indeed."

"Oh, and he also says that during that period that you much continue on with your normal way of life, including sleeping with the lionesses," Rafiki replied.

"Well maybe I could talk the lionesses into eating their kills away from Pride Rock," Simba replied, "but there's bound to be some carcasses there now, which means..."

"A struggle indeed," Rafiki replied gravely.

Simba looked thoughtful a moment, then thought of an idea, if he were to deliberately concede the kingdom...

A tricky thought, came a voice in his head, but if you give it up now, you'll never get it back, you'll never again be king of these lands, never see your child, and of course any new king will kill the old king's cubs. Simba shivered at the thought.

"There is a problem my king," Rafiki asked, noticing Simba's momentarily pre-occupied look.

"I, was just thinking of something," Simba replied, "but I don't think it would work."

"A pity," Rafiki said, "well, I wish you luck my king."

"Thanks," Simba replied, then deciding he couldn't wait any long, said, "I'll see you later," and left.
-------
Thinking ahead on how he was going to deal with any leftover meat from the lionesses' recent kills, Simba wasn't paying as much attention as perhaps he should have been to his immediate surroundings, and so some way into his journey suddenly blundered across a pack of wild dogs, and a half-eaten kudu carcass. Although the king knew he himself was no longer as limber as he once had been, the pack wasn't numerous, comprising only perhaps ten dogs, all of them in a torpid state from having gorged heavily, and so he could see but one outcome if he couldn't stop his hunger getting the better of him.

The same thoughts had obviously worked their way into the minds of the dogs who all moved away to give the lion room, all but one male who stood between Simba and the carcass, and asked, "who are you?"

"I'm king Simba," he replied through gritted teeth as he tried to control his rising hunger, "and I would like to ask you a favour."

"And what favour would that be," the dog asked.

"I would like you to go to Pride Rock now and tell my mate Nala to meet me at the waterhole," Simba replied.

"I will do my best to carry out that wish then, sire," the dog said, "I will tell her you wish to meet her at that waterhole."

"Thank you," Simba replied, and then turned his attention back to the carcass of the Kudu, or rather, getting away from it, though this proved to be less than easy as his hunger had continued to grow during the short conversation until it was now...
11131211221.title: Tough Trial

111312112211.content:
...Beyond his control, for despite all of his efforts, he was unable to prevent himself taking one step towards the carcass, and then another, and a third... Finally he was standing over the carcass, and despite one last supreme effort to avoid his obvious fate, he started to eat.

Despite the dogs' own meal earlier, there was still enough meat on the carcass for at least three normal lions to stuff themselves solid, which unfortunately for Simba meant simply a longer, larger meal. At first, the dogs standing on the sidelines saw nothing unusual about the king's eating, yet as time went on they began to get concerned, both for themselves, but perhaps more-so for him, for his stomach continue to swell larger and larger. The king himself was also worried, the impala the day before had been bad enough, yet there was at least half as much meat again here as there had been on the impala, so surely he'd do himself an injury if he tried to eat it all.

Despite all concerns though, Simba continued to gorge rapidly as he surpassed first his own previous natural limits, and then the limits to which the impala had taken him, and all of this without the smallest sign of any permanent damage. Eventually, the colossal size of the meal began to put pressure not merely on his flesh, but also on his skeleton, his now burgeoning gut forcing his hips to spread wider apart than should have been possible as more and more space was sought to expand into.

Finally, after more than an hour, Simba's hunger finally abated, every last bit of flesh having been consumed, and immediately the lion's movements reduced to twitches. This time there was no chance of getting up as there bad been with the impala, not only was his belly so painfully tight that the slightest motion startled a guttural groan from the bloated lion, but even if he had been able to get upright, the immense size of his bloated stomach would have prevented both hind-paws touching the ground at the same time.
-------
It was night when Simba awoke again, though he couldn't tell if it was the same night, the next, or the second one after gorging. Well, he thought, there was going to be no denying now that he was fat, although looking down at himself he quickly decided that 'fat' might not be the right word, it would be the same as calling a giraffe 'tall' or an elephant 'big'. His belly was obviously larger of course, but then so was his chest from what he could see, perhaps even more so for it appeared to have 'risen' to be almost as round as his belly, giving his torso at least the appearance of a particularly large grub. Nor was his torso the only part of his anatomy to expand, his legs had also grown thicker, with slight wrinkles developing at the joints so as to allow his legs to bend properly. Even his tail felt heavier, though the king soon found it impossible to bend sufficiently to see it properly, the excessive flesh doing more than simply increasing his weight.

almost swimming in self-disgust, Simba nevertheless knew he'd have to move eventually, and so set about getting up, which proved slightly easier than he'd expected it to, but still somewhat more difficult than it had even after he'd left Rafiki's the last time. He was on his feet soon enough though, and a quick scan of his surroundings told him...
111312112211.title: Godly Meal

1113121122112.content:
...He was being watched, though it wasn't until she moved that He recognised the lioness, "Nala?"

"Yes it's me," Nala replied, coming forward, "a-are you okay?"

"Right now I feel fine," Simba replied, "but when I get near food..."

"I know, I saw the size of your stomach," Nala replied, "it's not-it shouldn't be possible to eat that much!"

"I won't disagree with that," Simba replied, "but I seem to have got on the wrong side of a spirit of some sort."

"Is that-can the spirits do that," Nala asked, shocked.

"This one can apparently," Simba replied, "and to beat it I have to not eat a thing for four-no, six days now."

"Not eat for six days," Nala exclaimed, "but you'll starve."

"Hardly," Simba replied, "have you had a look at me lately?"

Nala shook her head, then examined him more closely, "h-how did you get this big this quickly that's surely not natural either?"

"Well the first meal was an impala," Simba replied, "a whole impala, and the next was about half a gazelle, and finally the kudu."

Nala looked at Simba extremely concerned now, "you need to go and see Rafiki immediately!"

"I've been to see Rafiki," Simba replied, "That's how I found out I need to not eat for six days."

"And he can do nothing," Nala asked.

"Nope, apparently not," Simba replied, "now, are there any other carcasses at Pride Rock?"

"There are," Nala replied, "a couple of gazelle, both about half eaten."

"Can you go ahead and remove them please," Simba asked, "if I touch them I'll be overwhelmed, and will have to fast for an extra two days for each animal."

"I'll do that," Nala replied, "I'll come and get you when it's done."

"Thanks," Simba replied, and lay down to wait. At first he was happy enough about this, but...
1113121122112.title: Observer to Gluttony

11131211222.content:
...He had a dream, although at first he didn't realise that it was so. Simba snorted as the hot sun beat down, awakening him. At first he felt calm, at peace with the world until he realised that he'd not the slightest clue where he was. "Hello," he called out, "anyone there?" When this failed to elicit a response, he scrambled up, and shouted, "anyone there?"

"I am," said a voice behind him. Started, Simba turned to see a a wildebeest standing there.

The lion could tell at a glance that it wasn't a normal wildebeest, for it was black as night, from the tip of its nose to the tip of its tail there wasn't a single hair that wasn't black, "who are you."

"Your friend the monkey calls me the Black Leporid," the wildebeest replied.

"Why are you here," Simba asked.

"Your friend has convinced me to come and talk to you," the black wildebeest replied, "personally I don't see the point, I know already that you're a glutton and will be until the end of your days."

"But I'm not a glutton," Simba replied, then instantly regretted saying it, "I'm, I-"

"Not a glutton hm," the wildebeest asked, "well let's test it shall we?" and with that dropped as though it were dead.

For a moment, Simba stood transfixed, then moved close and said, "a-are you okay?"

Very well, your majesty, the voice seemed to be in his head now, which is more than you'll be soon enough.

"What, what are you-" Simba began before his stomach rumbled loudly and an unnatural hunger overcame him, forcing him to spend every effort of his concentration to prevent himself from immediately beginning to devour the carcass.

Very good, very good, the voice said, and now, of you can take even one step away from this carcass without touching it, i will free you from your gluttony, if not, well, we won't dwell on that until you finish eating.

That was the key was it, Simba wondered with the tiny part of his mind that wasn't going into simply preventing his hunger from overriding him, all he had to do was take take one step away and it was over? Of course, one step was all very well and good, but his hunger was rising ever higher, and soon enough it would be impossible to contain, so if he moved it would have to be now.
11131211222.title: Spirit Communion

111312112221.content:
At first it looked as though Simba might lose the battle, his hunger growing as it was, moment by moment, becoming ever harder to refuse. Despite the apparent hopelessness of the situation though, the king refused to surrender, clenching his jaws so tightly his teeth ground together.

It's useless to struggle, the voice said, you can't refuse.

But. I. Am. Simba cried in his mind, I. Will. Succeed.

Impossible, the voice said, you cannot win, your glutton won't allow it.

We'll. See Simba replied, though he himself didn't believe it, for even within his mind the words felt more like groans. Nevertheless, he continued to clench his jaws desperately searching for a way - any way - to fight back. No matter how much he struggled though he couldn't turn away, and if he couldn't turn he couldn't escape. Or could he? Suddenly, an idea began to worm its way into his thoughts, and since he'd no other options he considered it.

More moments passed as the idea grew within Simba's mind, and then slowly, the lion began to prepare for what would surely be one of the most difficult tasks he'd ever faced. It seemed to take an age, but after just a few hunger-addled moments, he finally managed to get enough of his mind onto one thought so begin acting upon it, bringing himself, inch by inch into a sitting position, and then once that was over, crouching down. Finally he was ready, and after a few moments, made the jump.

Nooo, said the voice, as Simba sailed over the carcass of the wildebeest, taking one step away from the carcass on landing as his momentum carried him forward, no, you couldn't have.

I. Did. It. Simba said, still clenching his teeth, I. Did. It.

There was a moments pause, then the voice finally said, in a dark tone said, very well king, you have succeeded, for now.

Simba suddenly felt his hunger drop away, but as thankful as he was for this, he still said, "and in the real world, will you take my hunger there too?"

After a long moment, the voice finally said, I will, though only from this moment.

"That's enough," Simba replied.

We shall see, the voice said, farewell, sire.
-------
Simba snorted in the evening cool, well, that had been a strange dream, he wondered if it had had any significance. He hoped so, it would be dreadful to think of the monstrous hunger he'd suddenly been afflicted with to still be there, it would make his job nigh impossible. Looking down at himself, he was slightly appalled to see how large his gut was now, all this from but a day? Even if the hunger were gone, its legacy would make life difficult- Suddenly he heard a noise behind him and turned to see...
111312112221.title: Free Yet Burdened

111312112222.content:
Unfortunately for Simba, he'd left it a fraction of a second too late to contemplate his escape, and so before he could even raise a paw frow the ground, his hunger overtook him.

As Simba ate, a peculiar thing began to happen, for instead of the meal entering his stomach as normal meat would it seemed to bypass the hours of digestion, simply ending up on his body. This might have been acceptable if the carcass were that of a gazelle, but the wildebeest was in fact larger than he himself, so the direct transference was going to see him ending up a lot heavier.

The change was at first most noticeable on Simba's belly, with the tuck up behind his ribs, not large in any case, quickly disappearing entirely. The 'centre' of expansion moved forward soon enough so that his whole torso began to resemble a balloon slowly being inflated, which was in fact more-or-less the case. His torso wasn't the only place to change though, for as he ate more and more, his limbs began to get thick, followed soon after by his tail, which soon looked worse for the way it expanded, not gradually along its length but abruptly, like a worm pushing down a too-small tube. The only parts that didn't appear to change noticeably were his neck and head, but even here the expansion eventually began to have an effect, the rolls building up on his neck, although invisible beneath his mane, started to restrict his ability to turn his head.

All of these changes remained unnoticed though, as Simba, his mind almost catatonic with revulsion of his gluttony, simply had no time to process what was going on. Finally though, there was not a scrap of meat left on the carcass, in his hunger the lion had even crushed the skull in order to clean it back to bare bone. Finally in control of himself once again, the lion finally had the time to take stock of the changes, and the revulsion he's felt for his gluttony returned, redoubled. He was by now a parody of his former self, so fat he felt he could be mistaken for an adolescent hippo.

Simba had only a limited amount of time to process the effects of his recent meal though, for very soon he heard a familiar voice behind him, "ah, I see you've finish your meal."

Simba turned, a process that took just a little longer this time, find himself facing, an eland, once again black as night from nose to tail, "you, you made me-"

"I did nothing," the eland replied, "I simply opened up a deep deep desire you've long held but never dared reveal, now shall we talk about gluttony once again?"

"And if we don't you'll make me eat an eland," Simba said, more a statement than a question.

"Oh it won't be me making you eat it," the eland replied, "but yes, if you still refuse to admit your gluttony I'll demonstrate it once again."

Simba shuddered at the though, he was big enough now, after just a wildebeest, how big he'd be after an eland... "Will you let me go if I can resist this time?"

"Possibly," the eland replied, "if you're foolish enough to try it."

There was more truth in that statement than Simba would have liked, but he was also unwilling to let anyone, even a spirit as powerful as this get the better of him. "Okay then," he said, "..."
111312112222.title: Dream Feast

choices: "...I don't think I could go without food that long"
1113121122221.content:
"...We'll talk."

"Ah, so you're willing to admit that' you're a glutton," the eland said, "that's a start."

"I wasn't a glutton before you came," Simba said firmly.

"Oh I think you were," the eland said, "all those eating contest with your friends, sounds like gluttony to me, and not just any sort of gluttony either, you wanted to prove you were the biggest glutton around."

"I wanted to prove I could eat more than they could," Simba said, but was uncertain now, he'd forgotten about the eating contests, which made him suddenly less certain.

"Exactly, gluttony," the eland said.

"But you made it so I'd be able to eat more too," Simba said accusingly, "so I could, and would eat anything I found."

"Yes, I helped you unlock a deeply held desire," the eland said.

"but I'm a king now," Simba replied, "that's not, I don't act like that any more, I don't want to act like that any more."

"Ah, well, there's the issue isn't it," the eland said, "you're right that king shouldn't be too much of a glutton, but if you want to be a king you need to prove you have what it takes."

"And how do I do that," Simba asked.

"By not eating for, shall we say, two days," the eland said, "two days without, one for each animal, and you must live like a king while doing it, you cannot go off somewhere and just hide."

"And what happens if I eat something before then," Simba asked, uncertain of his capability to resist any food at all given his recent actions.

"Then I will raise it to six days," the eland said, "two days for each animal, and then again to three days for each, and then four, and so on and so on."

"Aren't there any other options," Simba asked.

"Well I could always make you a rogue again," the eland said, put you back in the jungle with your friends, and ensure you're never disturbed."

"But if I hadn't gone back to face Scar..." Simba let the sentence hang.

"Oh I'm not completely heartless, the eland said, your dear Nala would have come across another rogue capable of doing the same, and without the same emotional constraints."

"If I go back to being a rogue I'd still have to hunt for myself," Simba said.

"Oh not quite," the eland said, "if you were to be sent back you'd be able to subsist on bug forever more."

For a moment Simba was willing to agree, that option had a certain draw to it, but, "would I remember anything of this, of being a king?"

"only as a vivid dream," the eland replied, "but yes, you would."

"What about Kiara, my daughter," Simba asked, "would I remember her?"

"Certainly," the eland said, "she's important to you, so your dreams of her might be quite vivid."

"You said I'd never be disturbed," Simba said, "does that mean I'd never meet a lioness?"

"Would any lioness, even a rogue, want a fat, weak, bug-eating glutton," the eland asked.

"Fat, weak," Simba asked, "why would I be fat and weak?"

"Well bugs are a plentiful food," the eland said, "and you don't have to do a lot to get them, so..."

"So I'd never build up the muscles to catch any real food," Simba said, "and of course I suppose you'd ensure that any lioness found me disgusting."

"I don't think I'd have to do much there," the eland said, "most lionesses aren't kindly disposed to that at the best of times."

"But I'd dream vividly of my daughter," Simba said, "I'd want a daughter I could never have."

"Yes," the eland said.

"Would I be able to change anything at a later date if I wanted to," Simba asked.

"We'd have to see," the eland said, "but I'm not wholly against it."

"So either a hard-pressed king, or a nightmare haunted rogue," Simba said.

"That's right," the Eland replied, "and while I might agree to a change later, I'd leave you be for a while, so you'll still want to chose wisely."

"Okay then," Simba said, then thought for a few moments, before saying, "..."
1113121122221.title: Dicussion of Gluttony

11131211222212.content:
"...I don't think I could go without food that long."

"So you wish to be a rogue again then," the eland said.

"I don't, no," Simba replied, "but given the way I've been acting since I met you..."

"One rogue lifestyle coming right up then," the Eland said, and then it suddenly reared up, and before Simba coult think to react, brought its great horned head down upon his own.
-------
Simba awoke feeling lost, the dream had been so real, almost like a memory, he'd been a king, with a mate and a daughter... Except that that was unlikely he though with a shake of his head, the few females that had passed through here had been rather uninterested in him, even disdainful. He couldn't blame them either he thought ruefully, he was in a rather sorry state, fat, lazy, weak-willed and gluttonous. He'd denied the accusation when they'd first been made of him by a rather high-minded lioness by the name of Chaguzi, but had since come to accept, if not like them.

It was his upbringing that had been the problem, perhaps if he'd been found by someone other than his friends he might have become an admirable figure, but... Oh it was no use thinking that now he thought mournfully as he pushed against his rounded gut with a paw, and watched as the flesh welled up around it, fat, lazy, weak-willed, and gluttonous, perfect words to describe him. And he couldn't change it, that was the most annoying thing, oh he'd tried before, but his friends had always dissuaded him from it as being 'too much work for too little', and he'd always agreed with them after a few days, because, well, they were his friends, and he was, he had to admit, always ready to take the easy way. He had been anyway, but then Kamili had come, and she had been accommodating of his failings, and his rather errant ways, and things might have been joyous, but for the rogue who had been following her, a rogue as strong and fast as he was weak and slow, and the promise of happiness had been broken...

Simba glanced over at his friends to check they were still asleep, and rose quietly, and moved off into the jungle, seeking solace. He dearly wanted a mate now he knew, but to get one he'd have to cast aside his friends and his way of life, and that was just too high a price. If only he could convince his friends that this was something he needed to do, maybe then they'd-

Suddenly Simba's thoughts were broken by a rustling in the vegetation nearby. Immediately he froze, then after a few moments, moved forward slowly to investigate, finding the cause of the rustling to be...
11131211222212.title: Former Life

111312112222123.content:
...A large, no, huge black snake, larger than any he'd ever seen before, "who and what are you?"

"I," the snake hissed, "am but a humble sserpent, a denissen of thiss plasse."

"What are you doing here," Simba asked cautiously, this looked like some kind of strangler snake, and at the size it was, it looked like it might possibly consider him as a meal.

"I was jusst looking for ssomething to eat," the snake replied, "but then I heard you ssorrowful ssoundss."

"I wasn't making any sounds," Simba replied.

"We sserptentss lissten to the ssoil," the snake said gently, "your sstamping and passing were the ssoundss I heard."

"My thoughts are nothing to concern you," Simba replied, turning away, "you just be on your way."

"Ass iss you wissh," the snake replied, but instead of leaving it slithered silently closer to the brooding lion.

The first Simba knew that the snake had not in fact gone about its business was when it suddenly popped up in front of him a minute later, "perhapss you would care to tell me your troubless."

"I told you, they' none or your-oof," Simba began, turning away, or trying to but finding the snake coiled tightly around one leg, so that when her tried to take a step, he fell over. He moved quickly, trying to get up, but somehow the snake moved faster, coiling tightly around his other foreleg and neck, with enough left over to coil up before him, "let-let me go."

"Oh I ssoon will," the snake said, "but first I will dansse for you."

"I'm not interested in playing your games-," Simba began, struggling to escape, but stopped when the coil around his neck tightened enough to make his breath raspy.

"Oh but I inssisst," the snake said, raising most of the coil up so that his head would have stood level with Simba's had the lion been standing, "my dansse will be the dansse of the sserpentsss." Slowly it began to sway its upright portion, "I am ssure you will find it sso very seddusssing." The lion didn't want to watch, but with the coil around his neck he knew resisting would be, unwise. At first the snake's swaying was simply that, but after a time it seemed to grow more meaningful. The snake watched as the lion's struggles stopped and his eyes seemed to glaze over, then said, "tell me your troublesss."

"I want a mate, and a cub," Simba replied, his voice flat and unemotional.

"Ah yess," the snake said, "the life of a rogue issn't very ssatissfying." It paused a moment, then said, "but you sseem not to have had much ssuccesss."

"I have not," Simba replied in the same flat, dull tone.

"And what iss the causse of thisss," The snake hissed.

"I'm fat, lazy, weak-willed and disgusting," Simba replied.

"And how did you gain thesse traitss," the snake asked, "ssurely not from your parentss?"

"No, from my friends," Simba replied, "they raised me in their ways."

"Ssome friendss," the snake said, "sshow me thesse sso-called friendsss."

"I will show you my friends," Simba replied, rising as the snakes coils dropped away. It was not a long journey, and at length they came to the clearing where Timon and Pumbaa were still soundly asleep, "there are my friends, the meerkat is called Timon, and the warthog is called Pumbaa."

"Ah, now I ssee," the snake hissed, "ssuch unussual friendss for your kind." It was silent a moment, then said, "and it iss they who are ressponssible for your faultss?"

"They didn't know better," Simba replied, "they raised me as best they could."

"But one cannot sstay in the nesst forever," the snake said, "and to be a lion iss to eat meat, so to be a full lion, you musst learn to eat meat, sstarting with thesse two."

"But they are my friends," Simba replied, his love for them overriding even the hypnosis of the snake, "I owe them my life."

"But you are sstill a child in your ssoul," the snake said, "to become a true lion you musst leave your home, leave the friendss and family of your youth, learn to hunt, and learn to eat meat."

"I can do that," Simba said.

"Good," the snake said, "sso conssume thesse two."

"But they are my friends," Simba repeated.

"Yess, but friendss you no longer need," the snake said seductively, "your life with them musst end if you wish to become a real lion, and sso besst to let them go." This time Simba was silent, so it went on, "to ssurvive you musst learn to hunt, but to hunt you musst learn to kill, and sso, you musst kill thesse two."

"I must learn to kill," Simba said, "but they, are, my friends."

"Friendss who hold you back are not friendss," the snake said, "thesse sso-called friendss will never let you grow up, and sso they musst go."

"They must-but they are," Simba said, as the part of him that was still him argued with the bit of him in thrall to the snake, "I cannot-"

"You musst," the snake was more insistent now, "the path to your dreamss sstartss with the death of thosse two."

"I-I," Simba began, but his voice sounded strangled.

The snake watched Simba's struggle, then decided to intervene, knowing it would be necessary to break the deadlock, "you musst do it, you must kill to become a true lion."

Simba looked up at the snake, his face contorted with emotion, but the snake was ready for this, and quickly raised itself up and began to 'dance'. For a few moments, the lion watched the snake sway, and then...
111312112222123.title: Seductive Serpent

1113121122221231.content:
...Succumbed to its hypnosis, his eyes glazing again.

The snake would have smiled had it the lips to do so, it had won, the lion had professed to be weak-willed, but his struggle was proof that he was anything but, but in the end even his strength wasn't enough, "you will eat them."

"I, will, eat, them," Simba said.

"You will eat them," the snake hissed, "and you will do it now."

"I will do it now," Simba said, and trudged slowly towards his friends, still blithely unaware of the fate that awaited them. As he stood over them, his eyes began to tear up for what he knew he was about to do.

"Now, do it now," the snake said, "let their deathss unlock your true potential."

Simba resisted for just a moment more, then struck. Timon was first, his tiny body offered no resistance to the lion's powerful jaws, and then with one toss of his head the big cat turned him around in his mouth, and he was gone, forming, just for a moment, a bulge in his former friends oesophagus.

Pumbaa quickly followed his tiny friend into death, for one swipe from Simba was all it took to open his jugular, though he survived just long enough to awaken, look up and murmur, "wha' Simba wh-" before life left him.

By this point Simba's tears were flowing freely, his sorrow too much for even the snake's control over him to quash, but this display bothered the serpent little, even revelled in it, as this emotion weakened the lion's defences, "good, good, now, eat, let your friend'ss flesh become your own, let hiss blood ssusstain you." This time there was no hesitation, the big cat's head lowered, and began to tear chunks out of his former friend's body.

Minutes passed as Simba slowly reduced his former friend to bare bones. Of course, Pumbaa was not a small warthog, and comparatively heavily built, so the lion shouldn't have been able to finish a half of the carcass, yet he did somehow, though he quickly had to from a crouching position to half lying down to accommodate his ever-growing stomach.

By the end of the meal Simba's stomach was so large that had there not been a complete skeleton, an observer might have wondered if the warthog had not been swallowed whole. Filled well beyond its natural limit, the organ pushed up under his rib-cage, compressing his lungs so that he could only breath in short pants, while at the other extreme it forced his upper hind-leg out awkwardly so that the paw stuck up almost vertical, the only part of his anatomy to rise higher than his impossibly-bloated gut.

"Very good," the snake hissed encouragingly, "very good, now, ssleep, let it digesst, let your friend'ss flesh become your own."

"Yes," Simba panted, "yes, I will rest," and with that rolled over entirely onto his side, let his head drop to the ground, and closed his eyes.

the snake watched as Simba's breaths slowed down, and became regular before sliding away, the first part of his plan had worked almost perfectly.
-------
Simba could tell something was up as soon as he awoke, though for a moment he couldn't figure out what. Blearily, he opened his eyes, though all this told him that the sun was well up now, though this tickled him, normally he was up much earlier than his friends, so it was odd that this wasn't the case now, and odder than his friends hadn't come to wake him. Maybe they were off bug-hunting he thought, yawning and rolling himself upright, then noticing the skeleton. This immediately worried him, he'd never killed anything, and never eaten real meat since he'd left the Pridelands, so where... "Guys," he called out, rising now, "guys, are you there?" The forest remained quiet however, so he turned back to the skeleton, and with a sort of morbid interest, rolled it over.

At first Simba didn't recognise the skeleton, his former friend's face had been much rounder than the narrow skull the lion saw now, but the tusks were unmistakable. No, he thought, terror overtaking him, no, he couldn't have, no, surely. Tears began to form in his eyes as he tried to deny his action, but this proved impossible, so he turned and ran.

Simba's flight was soon at an end though, as he quickly discovered that his once-friend had left another legacy besides a picked-clean skeleton. Most lions would not have been troubled with running some hundreds of metres at a dead sprint, but Simba wasn't like other lions, he'd never had to hunt for his meals, nor had he ever really had the inclination to race his friends, so running was hard enough for him, and now his weight was markedly higher thanks to his recent, unnaturally large meal. These handicaps showed markedly as within a few paces he'd dropped from the closest approximation of a run he could manage, to a heavy, rather clumsy lope, and then lower still to a walk, by the end of which his chest was heaving and his heart racing, so unused was he to such exertions.

Simba wandered aimlessly for a time, lost in his sorrows, before be tripped over a root, and thumped to the ground. In a strange way, this minor fall was enough to galvanise the grieving lion into a course of action, for even as he picked himself up, he decided to...
1113121122221231.title: End of Life

11131211222212311.content:
...Hunt down the snake, it would brink his friends back, but it might give him a tiny bit of satisfaction to end the life of the one that had ended-no been responsible for ending theirs.

Simba quickly found, however, that his quest for vengeance wouldn't be easy, for the snake had left little scent, so he had to track it mostly by the path of crushed vegetation it left, a slow and rather laborious method that left him wondering at times whether he was on the right trail.

At length though, Simba's search for his quarry finally proved successful, the snake apparently sunning itself on a large flat rock next to one of the waterholes he and his friends had once favoured, though it looked up as he approached, "ah, sso you have ssought me out, perhapss, sso ass-"

"To end your life, beast," Simba replied angrily as the snake uncoiled itself and slithered closer, "to end your life for the evil to had me do."

"Ah, sso quick to anger," the snake seemed disappointed, "sso quick to turn asside, to deny my assisstansse-"

"Enough of your lies," Simba roared, and struck out.

The snake had been expecting this, and managed to dodge the strike, coiling around the offending forepaw, and then the other, parting them and bring Simba crashing to the ground,, before wrapping itself around his neck, "watch me dansse, watch me dansse and be ssedussed."

"No," Simba growled, and then in a move that seemed not to have been expected by the snake, darted his head down and right, and biting hard at the coil around his limb.

"No," the snake hissed, "no, thiss cannot be." It tried to tighten its coils around the lion, but Simba's strike had caught it high on its length, and so it was unable to do much as the lion bit hard, closing his jaws slowly, twisting his head this way and that as his teeth sand deeper and deeper, finally the great serpent lay still, its coils loose and easily shrugged off.

Simba felt a small bit of satisfaction at his victory, this monster would no longer trouble him, but the victory felt hollow, this death hadn't reduced his sorrow for the loss of his friends, and had left him with the probably of what to do about the body, that given time would rot down and despoil this once favoured place.
11131211222212311.title: Vengeance

111312112222123111.content:
For a few moments, Simba tried to decide whether the try to remove the snake, or just leave it and move on away from this part of the jungle, but then a beguiling idea began to grow in his mind. He quashed it at first, there was no way he'd survive, he'd either choke on it, or it would split his belly wide open, but then, did such a death matter now, would not death be release?

Even before he had fully committed to the idea, Simba picked up the snake's now-limp head in his mouth, testing its weight, then tossed it and tried to catch it, but it proved heavier than he expected, and so it hit the ground. He tried again, and then a third time, but each time the snake's head dropped too fast for him to get a grip on it, so, by now determined to consume the whole of the snake, or die trying, he lay down and grabbed the snake's body near its head and turning it upwards so that finally he was able to get it deep enough into his gullet for his throat muscles to grab it and begin the long slow process of dragging the serpent's great length to a final end in his gut.

For a short time, Simba remained lying down, but as he took in the snakes coils resting immediately next to him, he felt the resistance increase, and so rose and moved closer to the pile that constituted the main body of the snake, tossing his head periodically to keep the thick serpentine form from beneath his paws. This ultimately proved to be a mistake, as he was just about to settle down, when a final toss upset the coiled pile of the snake's main body, sending a loop sliding down the back of the pile, and into the water with a gentle splash.

At first Simba paid this event no mind, it didn't matter if the snake's body was in the water, he'd simply swallow it regardless. However, this proved not to be quite so easy as he imagined, for as he tossed his head again, to try and give himself a little more slack, another coil slid down, this one heavy enough to begin a slow cascade that dragged the rest of the snake's length into the water. The lion's eyes opened wide as he saw what was happening, then dashed forward to try to keep some of the snake's length on the rock, but its slick scales slid through his paw, faster and faster, until he realised it was hopeless, but by then it was too late, his footing too insecure to prevent him from being dragged over the edge along with his intended meal.

Simba was underwater for only a few moments before breaking the surface, but he knew it wouldn't last, the snake's weight seemed less in the water, but he could only keep his head up by constant swimming, and he knew he'd be unable to keep it up for more than a few minutes, so he quickly cast around for some way to save himself, luckily spotting a rock barely a body-length to his left. Swimming proved harder than merely staying afloat though, for at every stroke the weight of the snake dragged his head down and back, so that he had to stop every couple of strokes to tread water to get his breath back, a process not aided by the way the snake's breadth made breathing at all a real challenge. Finally though, the lion's determination paid off and he reached the rock, resting his forequarters on it to keep his head safely above the water.

Secure now in his position, Simba relaxed a little, allowing his throat muscles to begin again their work of drawing in the immense serpent. Time passed as the snake disappeared, inches at a time down the gullet of the lion. It wasn't an easy passage by any means, for the closer he got to the middle of the snake, the wider its body became, stretching his throat, and even at its widest, stressing his jaw, but he continued. Even once he's got past the snake's widest though, he struggled, the great coiled mass stretching his stomach tighter and tighter, yet somehow it held, even well beyond its theoretical limit. It wasn't just his stomach under stress either, for as his stomach grew larger, it began to push his hind-legs outwards and upwards until as the last of the snake disappeared between his jaws, his high-legs were almost horizontal.

Finishing his gargantuan meal brought Simba little pride, not because he was dissatistfied, but simply because one coil of the snake was bulging up under his ribcage, exerting a dangerous pressure on his lungs, making him feel sluggish and sleepy, so much so that he could just barely keep his hold on the stone.
-------
Simba yawned widely as he awoke, lying on his side on the bank of the waterhole. He could tell immediately that something was up, yet couldn't figure out what it was at the moment. "Guys, are you there," he asked blearily, "guys?" There was no answered though, so he assumed they'd gone off the find something else to eat, and so decided to see where they'd gone. This proved rather harder than he'd expected though, as he seemed to have gained a lot of weight all of a sudden. Just as he got to his paws, the lion's mind was awash with memories of the recent past, and the emotions they brought, longing, sorrow, anger, grim determination. Finally though, the wash faded, and he was overcome with...
111312112222123111.title: Long Feast

1113121122221231112.content:
...Determination. The serpent had been right about one thing he knew, to gain the lifestyle he wanted he'd have had to leave his friends behind, and well he no longer had any friends did he, so why not make the best of their absence? Some doubt entered his mind as he took a few steps and found himself waddling, his recently increased weight swelling his gut out so much that walking normally was out of the question, but that just fed into his determination, so what if it took him a year to get into shape, he had all the time in the world now.

After a few hours, Simba was, not less confident in his eventual success, but more aware of just how far he had to go. A life of ease to the present had left him comparatively weak, combined with the massive amount of extra weight, he'd acquired over the past few days meant that any movement above a slow, waddling lope was more-or-less out of the question, and even that he could hold for barely more than a few moments. Nevertheless, he knew he could, no, he would do it, sooner or later, he'd lose this extra flesh.
-------
Tears ran down Simba's face as he lay back, tears of sorrow for his lost friends, of rage at the memory of the serpent, and of fear for his future. His determination to take advantage of his newfound freedom was in tatter, torn to pieces by a new, unbounded gluttony. His overly-engorged stomach made less of an impact on his now unnaturally large belly, but he knew in his own mind that he couldn't, or at rather shouldn't have been able to eat anything like as much as he had. Or was this the new normal for him, after all, he'd swallowed that damnable serpent hadn't he, and it was much larger than this present meal, so maybe that somehow had stretched his stomach out. This thought cheered him up not at all.

Even now though, a tiny fraction of his determination remained, unwilling to admit there was absolutely no chance. The problem with the jungle was that he was simply too good at finding food here, out on the savannah he'd surely have much more trouble, and so much more success at losing weight. The savannah was also where most lions lived, so he'd be reminded of his eventual goals much more often, maybe. That would have to wait for later though, for now there was little to do but lay back and wait for his current meal to digest.
-------
Simba stood and stared out across the savannah. He was right on the edge now, almost ready to leave the jungle that had kept him so well for so long. Some of his determination was returning, even though he'd had a second colossal bug meal since swallowing the serpent, causing his belly to hang just that little bit lower still. From now on though, such feasts would be few and far between, he'd have to work hard for every scrap, and for a time would very likely go hungry, but that was okay, the less he ate the more he'd lose. Finally prepared, in his own mind at least, he stepped out from under the green trees of his former home, and waddled towards a new, better future.

At first when he'd started out, the savannah had looked desolate, but this proved not to be the case, for soon enough he met...
1113121122221231112.title: Path in Mind

1113121122222.content:
"...We'll see who's foolish." Simba was sure he'd have the edge this time, he felt ready for anything.

"As you wish, sire," The eland sneered, then dropped. Although Simba had thought he'd be ready for the hunger, the sheer intensity of it was this tine even more overwhelming than the last time, to the point that he was utterly unable to prevent his body moving forward, one slow, faltering step at a time. By some supreme effort, he was able to pause for a few moments as he stood over the carcass, before the voice, once again more felt than heard, spoke, very good, but it's too little too late, you've lost, and with that the lion felt any last shreds of self control drop away, preventing him from even attempting to hinder his unimaginable hunger.

Of course, the eland was very much larger than the wildebeest had been, and so should have taken much longer to eat, except that it didn't. Of course, Simba was eating furiously, but even this couldn't account for the speed at which the meat was disappearing, and indeed a closer observation might have noticed that right around the are where he was eating, the meat was evaporating, apparently turning into a sort of red-violet smoke than wafted over his head, especially into his nose and what bits of his mouth that momentarily weren't full of meat.

As before, this meal bypassed Simba's stomach, ending up directly on his body, only with much greater speed. Already larger than any lion should have been, he quickly became larger still. As before, his torso once again took the lead, almost seeming to explode as his body sought somewhere to store the immense intake. It was not just his belly that took on more weight of course, for even as his growing gut forced his legs into an ever more splaying stance, so his shoulders flanks, and hips inflated too, soon forming a uniform wall from his also ever-growing neck rolls back to his tail-head, and from the top of his now indistinguishable shoulder blades down to below his elbows and knees.

Soon enough, Simba - or at least the tiny part of his mind that wasn't preoccupied with an overwhelming feeling of revulsion at his now undoubted gluttony - began no notice that movement was becoming almost impossible as his by now colossal torso forced his stance to spay so much that not all of his legs could touch the ground at any one time, a fact which wasn't helped in the slightest by the fact that his neck-rolls were by now so numerous and so large as to be holding his head just about fixed. Nevertheless, the hunger was insatiable, and so giving up on attempting to move, the lion instead abandoned his by now futile attempts to try to move from one part of the carcass to another, and instead tried to use his ever less flexible forelegs to try to draw the carcass to him. This should have been impossible, for although the carcass was denuded of a good portion of its flesh, it should still have been too heavy for him to manoeuvre. This proved not to be the case, however, and so the feast continued.

By now Simba was a grotesque parody of his former self, looking from afar not unlike the sort of grub he'd once dined on so many years ago in his youth. This didn't stop him though as he continued to gorge, oblivious to anything but the meal before him. The meal couldn't last forever though, and finally there was no meat left on the carcass, at which point the unnatural hunger left him. For a moment he wondered whether to bother trying to take stock of his condition, but then decided he might as well. His head seemed to be the least encumbered, for he found he could open his jaws a little over half-way before running into the flesh of his neck, and his ears still retained some freedom as well, though his hearing was dulled when they pressed too heavily against the rolls pushing forward from his neck over the top of his skull. From there on though, things got steadily worse, his neck was so behung with rolls of flesh as to allow him only a few degrees of flexibility side-to-side and up-and-down, and even then their great weight made holding even the extremes of those limits a struggle. His legs were a little better, for he found he could his could, albeit with great difficulty, move them at least a bit within their fleshy cocoons, his fore-legs, more than his hind ones, and extend the claws on all four paws, though it was obvious that they'd never be useful against any creature that wasn't actively trying to commit suicide. Finally, his tail proved even worse than his neck, so thick and heavy with fat, that what meagre muscles it still contained struggled to produce more than a nearly imperceptible twitch.

Simba was in despair now, why had he been so foolish as to challenge this spirit? It had proved once before that it was much more than he, and yet he'd still allowed his pride and bravado to get the better of him. Truly, he realised, he was not cut out to be a king, he was too impatient, too-

Suddenly a voice from behind him said, "you seem to be having a bit of trouble there sire." It was a voice that was all too familiar, yet now...
1113121122222.title: In Too Deep

11131211222222.content:
...Held a distinctive cackle, one he could all too easily place, "hyena."

"Ah, yes, very well recognised," said the voice, moving around from behind him. It was indeed a hyena, although as before, entirely black, "I though that since your aim with the herbivores was apparently simply to eat them, that I'd have to find another way to, bring you to terms."

"What terms," Simba asked, his voice wheezy from the work being forced upon his lungs simply keeping his colossal form oxygenated. Nevertheless, even in his helpless state he couldn't help but let his claws slide out, such was his revulsion for the hyena.

"Now now sire," the hyena said, "getting angry won't help, because we both know I could kill you in a moment and not get a scratch, so how about calming down and for once listening to what I have to say, hm?"

Although he disliked the idea of doing anything the hyena wanted, Simba knew he had no choice, and so forced his claws to retract, and said, "go on."

"Well since its obvious that you've not the slightest control over your gluttony, I'll help you out there," the hyena said, "however, in return, I want my pound of flesh."

"A pound," Simba asked disbelievingly.

"Well, a pound, a ton, it's all the same right," the hyena replied, "anyway, since you've proven incapable of controlling even your most basic urges I doubt you'd ever make it as a king, right?"

"I was doing fine until-" Simba began.

"-Until you let your gluttony get the better of you," the hyena replied, more loudly, "so as I said, a poor king." the hyena's eyes glowed threateningly, as if daring Simba to contradict him, though by now the lion had wised up to this, and held his tongue. "Good to see you're finally coming to terms with your failings," the hyena continued after a few moments, "although things might have better for you if you'd been willing to admit them earlier, I might have been more lenient with my terms."

"What terms," Simba asked.

"Well I'm glad you asked actually," the hyena said, "now since you're apparently incapable of controlling yourself, it's going to have to be up to someone else to control you."

"And if I refuse," Simba asked, knowing it was a foolish thing to say, but still unwilling to completely submit to whatever this black beat wanted.

"Oh you don't want to do that," the hyena replied, "I mean you could, but I doubt you'd be king for long, after all, a lion who's fat as a cub will hardly be able to contest his territory with a vicious rogue, and I doubt most lionesses would respond well to such open displays of gluttony as you've shown."

"Perhaps there is room for negotiation," Simba said, "some arrangement we could come too?"

"Perhaps there is indeed," the hyena said, "and you know, I applaud you for your tenacity..."
11131211222222.title: Despicable Visage

choices: "...I couldn't put the ladies through the stress"
111312112222222.content:
"...But it's for nought, you can't give me anything I can't take."

"So you'll dictate to me terms," Simba asked, "and if I don't like them?"

"Then you're in for a hard time," the hyena said, "you can't refuse me."

Simba sighed, "very well, what are your terms, something to do with hyenas I take it?"

"Got it in one," the hyena replied, "when you became king you treated them very badly, very badly indeed."

"They killed the Pridelands," Simba replied, "I had no choice."

"Pah," the hyenas said, "it was one of your own responsible then, not the hyenas."

"Well they certainly didn't help," Simba replied, slightly weakly, not wanting to admit that the hyenas weren't responsible for any sort of suffering.

"Nor hinder," the hyena replied, "the Pridelands on your father would easily have been able to support both pride and pack."

"And so what is my fate," Simba asked, wanting to change the subject.

"Well here in fact you get a choice," the hyena said, "on the one hand you can allow the hyenas back in, or on the other you can become a hyena."

"I don't think I could stand either of those choices," Simba replied, coolly.

"Well you'll have to stand one or the other," the hyena said.

"Is there no other options at all," Simba asked.

"Oh yes, there are, but they're worse than those," the hyena smiled, "want to hear a few?"

"Do tell," Simba replied, though without enthusiasm.

"Gladly," the hyena said, "for example, I could make it impossible for you to lay so much as a claw on them, or bring a whole pack to you here, or turn your mate Nala into a hy-"

"Okay, enough," Simba said, "you've made your point."

"Ah, good," the hyena grinned, "so what'll it be, be a friend to them, or become one?"

"If I become a hyena, what happens to my cubs," Simba asked anxiously.

"Oh, they become the cubs of another king," the hyena said, "and don't worry about your mate either, she'll never even know you survived the stampede." There was a pause, then the hyena said, "so what?"

Simba sighed, and said, "very well..."
111312112222222.title: Forced Friends

1113121122222222.content:
